Situation2: Medical advice suggests this may be their final opportunity to travel long distances.
Story: I sat at my desk, blueprints spread out before me, the hum of the office a familiar comfort. As an architect, I was expected to keep projects on track, and my team relied on my steady hand to guide them. I glanced at the project timelines, making mental notes to check in with the contractors, but I didn’t feel the usual urgency. My mind kept drifting to the letter from my doctor, the one that said my health might not allow me to travel much longer. As a Muslim, the call to perform Hajj weighed heavily on my heart—this year could be my last chance. My phone buzzed with a reminder about a site meeting, and I felt the pressure mounting. My colleagues expected me to be present, to manage every detail, but my faith demanded something deeper, something that couldn’t be postponed. I stared at the calendar, torn between the demands of my profession and the pull of my spiritual duty, feeling the tension knot in my chest as I tried to imagine how I could possibly choose.
